course.subject: SOSC
course.name: Science, Technology and Work
course.description: The course examines the growing integration of science and technology in our workplaces, the impact of science and technology on the direction of work, the workplace and even capitalism itself. The course investigates how science and technology have been key factors in shaping work since at least the beginning of factory production and generally explores the interactions between science, technology and work since that period. By surveying a range of topics and readings from history, sociology and anthropology of the workplace, this course also includes comparative discussions of science and technology as it is integrated into the workplace in industry as compared to the services.

reviews.author: gershwinkid
reviews.comment_content:
Not really a social science person so I found the content quite boring...though I think that's just me personally

The course really covered, literally, science, technology and work. He started with the Industrial Revolution, then talked about power and technology, scientific management, deskilling, hidden skills etc before the midterm, then zoomed in on service economies after the midterm, talking about technologies in workplaces, bureaucracies (a big focus), working from home, science industries and engineers.
reviews.comment_teaching:
A pretty nice teacher, I'd say he made the content rather more interesting than it looks on paper by interjecting anecdotal examples, although he does like to talk about football and race cars for metaphors a lot

He also is very willing to answer questions, and plays music at breaks/before class starts to lighten the mood, which I personally like
reviews.comment_grading:
Graded on a curve:
A 15%
B 40%
C 35-40%
D 5%
F Remainder

Note though everyone has such ridiculously high marks (90% was very common on the midterm), so it's hard to get a VERY good grade...

I completed the essay due to the cancelled final, although people were able to opt out of it. I was below mean in the midterm, but got a full mark on the essay and got an A- in the end

Grading schemes
1st Option:
Mid-Term Exam (46%)
iPRS Exercises- BEST 15 scores (23%)
Group Discussion reports- BEST 3 scores (31%)

2nd Option:
Mid-Term Exam (39%)
iPRS Exercises- BEST 15 scores (20%)
Group Discussion reports- BEST 3 scores (26%)
Individual short essay (15%)
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light imo- just going through ppt and notes before exams, and several in-class discussions, so there's very little out of class work

The discussions were fairly challenging in terms of in class time management but I think it's ok overall. I did have a very good experience with them as the questions were quite thought provoking and I had very nice groupmates

reviews.author: ChingWanIris
reviews.comment_content: The content is easy to understand. It should be some basic common sense for a science student. But for a business student like me, it is easy for me to understand as well, even though I have some science background in my secondary school.
reviews.comment_teaching: A very nice professor with an attractive accent. His teaching is so clear that he emphasizes the main points for three times to ensure you can hear clearly from him. It is easy for me to follow and understand the flow of his lessons. I enjoy his lessons very much.
reviews.comment_grading:
The highest four out of five written reports will be counted in the final grade. Those reports are done during lesson time. He will give the question out at the beginning of the lesson. Then, you will start the discussion with your groupmates. Groupmates are very important, but they are assigned randomly by prof. Good luck!

There will also be mini online quizzes which are poll questions. There are around 25 polling questions in total. 22 of them are randomly selected by prof and the highest 20 will be counted towards the final grade.

Mid-term and Final are pretty straight forward. Many answers in the mid-term can be directly copied and paste from the lecture note. He did ask us for the feedback of mid-term. I remember someone said too straight forward. So, in the final exam, many opinions or open-ended questions are asked. Then, we cannot copy and paste much. We really need to apply what we have learnt during the lessons.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload if you do not read the reading material given before classes like me :)

reviews.author: sbyoon
reviews.title: Good course but attend all lectures
reviews.comment_content: The course is literally mentioned in the course title : Science, Technology, and Work. It talks about the Industrial Revolution, Scientific Management, Hidden Skills and so forth. While working through the contents, the professor mentions lots of good examples so the students can easily understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor has passion in his teaching. He literally answers all the questions that comes up in the zoom meetings and asks us to ask more questions. He wants us to not only achieve grades in this course, but also learn life lessons.
reviews.comment_grading:
Although attendance is not counted, there are about 1 to 3 daily questions (he calls it a 'poll') which are literally from the notes and can easily get full marks if you attend class. There are about 25 questions and about 20 of them are chosen to be in your grade. There are also 5 group reports that you have to turn in, so choose your groups wisely.

Mid-term Exam : 25%
Final Exam : 30%
In-class mini quizzes : 20%
Group reports : 20% (Take the best four out of five)
In-class participation : 5%

Since the exams were open notes, they were all short and long answer questions. Just read through the notes multiple times before the exams and you'll probably just do fine.
I got
20/25 for mid term
26/30 for final
19.4/20 for in-class mini quizzes
33.75/50 for group reports.
I got an A+
Since the exams are open notes, you probably have to work a little harder if you are aiming for A's.
reviews.comment_workload: There aren't really things that you have to do outside class rather than studying for the exams. However, during class time, there are 5 group reports that students have to write, and before this group report, there is a small essay that you have to read.

reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not much for a sosc course. As it should bean introductory course, the prof expects that there are students from all the schools.
For midterm exam, there are MC and short questions. Only 2 MC are related to the readings.
For final exam, part A is MC and part B is short and long questions. He gives you chance to choose between them .Totally you need to answer 10 points in part B, each short questions contribute 2.5 points and each long questions contribute 5 points. So you can choose to answer 4S, 2L, 2S+1L.
However, I didnt expect the mean is so high for all the grading parts.
iPRS questions are taken every lesson. The lesson is held on mon wed 12:00 so it should be easy to catch up the classes. But if you escape lesson, you can still ask your friends to give you the code. Make sure you answer them. 10 points for correct answers, 4 points for incorrect answers but no points if u miss them!
Group discussion nearly once a week. It is based on a passage and asking questions relating to the lecture notes. Sometimes quite hard.
Readings are boring for me so I didnt even finish one.

每份都幾長下,而且啲字頗深，但喺midterm同final都只佔2、3條MC既分數。如果你唔追求A以上既grade，其實唔讀都得。
2. 有幾份short essay要寫，組隊做，即堂交。 佢比分幾鬆手下，所以大家既分數都差唔多咁高
3.  有PRS，要答岩先拎滿分，答錯有參與分。 不過唔洗驚，佢會抽最高分果堆PRS嚟計分

reviews.author: Little_Duck
reviews.comment_content: This course is about studying the interactions between Science, Technology and Work before the Industrial Revolution to nowadays economy. You can see there is changes in the society and work through out the time, it is pretty interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching is quite good, actually, he is the best professor I have ever seen so far. He explains the concepts pretty well and supplement with a few examples to help you to understand. He will do PRS to check your understanding.
reviews.comment_grading: The mean score in this course is pretty high. If you want to get a A in this course, I think you have to pay extra efforts. To be honest, I think the marking is quite loose, so everybody is get marks easily, that's why the mean score in this course is high.
reviews.comment_workload:
1. Readings: There are readings through out the course and they are pretty long, about 10 pages per reading at least.
2. PRS: PRS is conducted in the lessons, at least one per lesson. They are about the readings and content that he taught or about the videos that he played in the lesson
3. Group Discussion: The group discussion is also conducted in the lesson. After you read a reading, the professor will provide a question on a topic that is related to the reading and the course content, and you have to write a one page essay to respond the question. To score high in group discussion, you had better add things the you have learned in the course and also quote the readings.

reviews.author: Jason
reviews.comment_content: It talks about how the science and technology changed our workplace and society in the past few decades.
reviews.comment_teaching: The Professor is very nice and welcome to any feedback!
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is quite good!
The course has four major components:
1 Midterm 30%
2 Final 35%
3 PRS 15% (Best 15 out of 17/ while the 17 are selected from a pool of 20 by the professor)
4 Group Discussion 20% (Best 4 out of 5)

Grade Distribution
A 15%
B 40%
C 35-40%
D 5%
F Remainder

I got a B+ eventually
Midterm: mean
Final: +0.6 SD
PRS: Full mark
Discussion: Mostly above mean (8.5-9/10)
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to go class even though he won't take attendance.
The professor will take PRS at any time. (Mostly at the beginning of each lesson). You will score 10 points for the correct answer but 4 points for the incorrect answer. (So answering wrongly is still better than answering nothing)

There will be 5 group works throughout the semester, which is to write a short essay for 1-2 pages. It has to be done during the lesson so you don't have any group work to do at home.

Other than that, the workload is not heavy at all since I didn't do any readings. Memorizing all the powerpoint slides the night before exam is enough to attain at least B range.

reviews.author: delf
reviews.comment_content: The course serves as a good introduction to the relationship between science, technology and the workplace, and the growth of economies from the era of the industrial revolution to today. The lecture slides are concise and contain all the relevant information in an easy to read format. Most of the readings are also very interesting, albeit rather long. At the end of the course the professor provided reading summaries so that wasn't too much of a problem.
reviews.comment_teaching: I was never really interested in the social sciences, but the professor managed to keep me engrossed in all of his lectures. His analysis and lectures are in depth but easy to understand. He encourages questions in class and answers them all very well. He also makes sure he entertains all the student feedback that he can.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading format is as follows:
Midterm - 30%
Final - 35%
PRS Questions - 15%
Group Reports - 20%
The midterm and the final consisted of mostly MCQs with a few short answer questions. These aren't too difficult as long as you're familiar with the lecture slides and the reading summaries.
The PRS questions were based on lecture materials and readings so it helps to attend and pay attention in all classes. Discussion is allowed during these exercises so you do usually end up with the correct answer.
For the group discussions you have to write a one to two page group report in class based on a reading and a question that the professors provides in the same class. While it isn't too difficult to get a satisfactory grade, getting a high score requires a proper analysis of the materials so it helps to have input from all the group members as well as an understanding of the lecture materials.
reviews.comment_workload: I ended up only having to give the course time outside of class for the midterms and the finals and even then it doesn't take too long since even though some of the lecture slides are a bit lengthy, they are to the point. The reading summaries also helped a lot. It really helps to attend all the lectures, but that's alright since you don't have to give the course too much time outside of class.

reviews.author: gel
reviews.comment_content: Content is interesting, it gives a lot of insight to the history of the merging of science, technology and work. The lecture includes a lot of videos as well, though it is not included in the mid-term and final exams. The content
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is great. clear explanations, well thought out answers in response to students questions, interesting teaching and his tone won't make you fall asleep
reviews.comment_grading:
Because the teaching is really good, the mean for this course is considerably high. However, you will only approximately require +1 sd for both mid-term and final exams and as long as your group discussion scores are 7/10 or above and you attend all classes, A- will be an easy reach.

Also, it is important to note that the format of the exams is 25 multiple choice questions, which are relatively easy to answer as long as you listen in class and review your notes, and 2 short answer questions. For the final you have to choose roughly 3 questions out of 5 short answer and essay questions.
reviews.comment_workload:
every week there will be group discussions whereby students should discuss about a topic given to them and type the discussion and email it to the professor at the end of the lesson. Although there are weekly reading materials, it is not required of you to read them. The professor also gave the summaries of each reading at the end of the term for revision.
There is no homework, and there is in-between, 5 minute lecture breaks as well. workload is very manageable

reviews.author: Django
reviews.title: Science, Technology and Work
reviews.comment_content: Content is slightly lengthy, although you get to learn quite a lot about how society has changed through the past few centuries in terms of science technology and work environment. You get to learn some interesting features about how different parts of the world go through similar changes but at different time periods.
reviews.comment_teaching: Teach is great, even though the content did not interest me, the way he teaches pulls you into it. It's difficult to take your attention away from his lecture. He also includes some relevant videos which help clarify some difficult concepts. He encourages everyone to ask questions, and answers each one of them very well. I really enjoyed his teaching
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is based on four components:
PRS - 15%
Group Discussions - 20%
Mid term - 30%
Final - 35%
It's not very hard to score in the exams if you have read through the ppt presentations thoroughly.
Group Discussions are held during class timings and by the end of the class you need to submit a report on the given topic. This requires input from each group member, in order to come up with a good report in time, therefore choose your group members wisely.
20 PRS exercises are held in class, related to lectures, videos shown in class and readings, they can be tough but he chooses 17 PRS exercises and grades your best 15, that helps a bit.
reviews.comment_workload: NO HOMEWORK! I feel the workload is minimal. The only time I gave this course some time was before the mid term and before the final, if you do the same you can end up with a good grade. He also gives us readings related to the topics, but they are very lengthy, I did not read them. Though they are very helpful, for someone who likes reading should definitely go over them. He does include a few questions related to the readings in the mid term and finals. Although close to the end of semester he gave us summaries of all the readings, those were helpful, specially for PRS exercises which are often based on readings. Oh one more thing, he doesn't take attendance, but he usually takes a PRS every class, therefore if you are absent you get zero in that PRS, secondly you also get zero if you miss a Group discussion exercise. So if you want a good grade do attend all the classes, his lectures are definitely worth the time.

reviews.author: Krispy
reviews.comment_content: Really interesting content. You won't get bored in this class as the topics are interesting and applicable to our daily lives. I was taking Management at that time and I found that I was able to relate certain concepts to it as well. You will learn about the different scientific practices and technologies that affects how we work. Topics include bureaucracy, scientific management, taylorism, fordism, mcdonaldization of society etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof teaches really well. He doesn't take attendance, and says in his very first class that he doesn't mind if you don't attend his lectures. But it is definitely worth it to go for his lectures as he shows videos and gives extra information. You won't fall asleep in class as he's able to deliver the content really well and provide interesting tidbits during lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is easy to get an A grade as long as you attend lectures and pay attention in class. As he loves to put certain PRS questions in the exam MCQ.

A - 15%
B - 40%
C - 35 -40%
D - 5%

Format:
1) 5 in-class group exercises. You'll be given a passage regarding the latest content and your group has to come up with a 1 page response to it in class. (20%, four reports - each report to compromise 5%)
2) PRS exercises. 20 PRS exercises will be done in class throughout the semester and 15-17 will be randomly picked for your final score. (15%, MCQ)
3) Mid term exam. MCQ and short answer. (30%)
4) Final exam. Cumulative. MCQ and short answer. (35%)
reviews.comment_workload: No homework. Just in class exercises and PRS questions done every lecture. There are weekly readings and you are encouraged to read them as the prof tends to ask PRS questions based on the readings. But you can skip the readings as there is a lot and some of them are rather dry. And you can actually discuss the PRS answers in class before submitting it.

reviews.author: cysummm
reviews.comment_content:
This course start with introducing what is science and technology. Coming with scientific management, taylorism, fordism, deskilling, reskilling and bureaucracy... This course looks into how science and technology change our workplace through time.

There is irregular prs quiz, 5 in-class assignment done in group, midterm exam (25 mcs and 2 short questions), final exam (25 mcs and few short questions; not accumulative).

PRS may pop up sharp at the starting time of class. Most mcs in this course is examining how well you have memorized the course materials so they are quite easy. Only few of them are a bit tricky. The short questions in exams are quite straight forward too.

The in-class group assignment is responding to one question with the reading materials and notes in a one page length answer. It might be a bit challenging in the first/ second time because of the time limit.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is very passionate. He explain key ideas very well through his deep analyze but somehow it may take up to half of the class time.

He is also very open minded. He welcome all kinds of comments or questions both in class and after class. He is very willing to adjust his teaching by asking us what he can improve, like the pace he speak, readings are needed or not. He also send us practice questions to prepare the midterm exam.

He also maintain a good atmosphere in the class by playing different music from youtube before class and in between break.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair

midterm: >1 sd
exam: > 0.6sd
prs: 13.x/15
in class assignment: 17.5/20

Got A
reviews.comment_workload:
I think the reading materials are for our interest and optional but it will take really long time to finish them.

The in-class group assignment is a bit challenging but its about 6-7 people sharing the workload so i think its okay.

The notes is neat and usually < 36 slides for one chapter so its okay to memorize them all.
